k m wrote:
> 
> 
> Hello,
> 
> A colleague and myself are beginning to implement JUnit tests. We are 
> facing a dilemma that I hope you can help us with. How are dependent 
> unit tests handled?

...by using another framework or by removing the dependency.

> For example, there are 2 independent methods that must be tested, but to 
> test them and clean-up they become dependent. So, the methods are 
> addRecordToDB() and deleteRecordFromDB(). Additionally, addRecordToDB() 
> will fail if the record already exists in the database.
> 
> To test that addRecordToDB() can add a new record, testAddRecordToDB() 
> must ensure that the record does not already exist, which relies on a 
> deleteRecordFormDB() message in setUp().
> 
> To test that deleteRecordFromDB() can delete an existing record, 
> testDeleteRecordFromDB() must ensure that the record already exists in 
> the database, which relies on an addRecordToDB() in setUp().
> 
> To test that addRecordToDB() fails if the record already exists, 
> testAddRecordToDBDuplication() must ensure that either
> 
> - the record does not already exist, which relies on 
> deleteRecordFromDB() in setUp() and 2 addRecordToDB() messages in the 
> test method OR
> 
> - the record already exists, which relies on 1 addRecordToDB() message 
> in setup() and 1 addRecordToDB() message in the test Method
> 
> These same issues also affect the tearDown() method.
> 
> Generically stated, should a test method's setUp() and tearDown() rely 
> on an untested method? If not, how can we avoid it? Is there a way to 
> enforce the sequence of test method runs?
> 
> Any advice would be appreciated. Thanks.

Short answer: Don't test the platform. JDBC works, so you don't need to 
test it.

Medium answer: Make each test start from empty tables, then you'll find 
out why that's a good solution (it works) and a bad solution (it's slow).

Longer answer: JUnit Recipes, chapter 10.
